news_header: Newly discovered engravings at a 16,000-year-old German site depict net fishing practices, marking it as the only known Upper Paleolithic site to visually represent such activities.
news_text: Recent research has revealed engravings on stones at Gönnersdorf, a German site dating back nearly 16,000 years, showcasing scenes of net fishing. This discovery, made using advanced imaging techniques, positions Gönnersdorf as the only known Upper Paleolithic site in Europe, and possibly globally, to depict net fishing. The engravings include fish surrounded by crosshatched lines likely representing nets. Excavations at the site have previously uncovered various artifacts, including animal bones and figurines, indicating a rich cultural context. The findings suggest that the area was a seasonal gathering spot for hunter-gatherer groups engaged in fishing.
